ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_0: And beggars and the destitute received a due share of their wealth.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_1: In whose wealth the suppliant and the deprived had a share.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_2: and in their wealth there was a rightful share for him who would ask and for the destitute.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_3: They assigned a share of their property for the needy and the destitute.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_4: And the beggar and the destitute had a share in their wealth.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_5: And in their wealth there was the right of the Sa'il and the Mahrum.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_6: And in their property was a portion due to him who begs and to him who is denied (good).
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_7: and the beggar and the outcast had a share in their wealth.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_8: And in their wealth the beggar and the outcast had due share.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_9: and sharing their possessions with the beggars and the deprived.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_10: And in their substance was the right of the beggar and non- beggar.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_11: and there was a share in their wealth for the beggar and the deprived.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_12: And in their wealth and possessions (was remembered) the right of the (needy,) him who asked, and him who (for some reason) was prevented (from asking).
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_13: And in their properties there was the right of the beggar, and the Mahrum (the poor who does not ask the others).
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_14: and in their wealth was a share for whosoever asked and for whosoever was prevented.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_15: And in their wealth, there was a share for the beggar and the deprived.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_16: And from their properties was [given] the right of the [needy] petitioner and the deprived.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_17: [51:19] and there was a share in their wealth [assigned] for the beggar and the deprived, [the latter being] the one who does not beg, because of his self-restraint.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_18: (And in their wealth the beggar) who asks from people (the outcast) he who does not beg from people nor is he given and nor do people realise he is in need; it is also said that the outcast means: the one whose wage and spoils are denied; and it is said that this means: the one who has a trade but whose life is hard and cannot earn his day's sufficiency (had due share) had an acknowledged right.
